value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">3.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">old words & new words; French & Latin. No grammar</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">held them tightly together. They were elastic, they</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">could be danced to & sung to. But they could</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">not follow the sound of the speaking voice.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-espe">Spenser</rs> then in the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-faer" key="Faerie Queene, The">Faery Queen</rs> seems like a</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">half articulate monster, rising from the depths of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">silence, <del>with</del> hung with the weeds & pearls of <del>that</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the deep sea in which the writer had been</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">submerged. <del>The Faery Queen</del>: <del>is</del> we cannot read it: <add place="above">the 
            <choice>
              <sic>Fr Q.</sic>
              <corr>Faerie Queene</corr>
            </choice></add></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">we cannot leave it unread. <del>This</del> is a poem without a plot;</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the metre, casting its regular fling, but somehow</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">comes to ground too [wholy?]. Unlike <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-gcha" key="Chaucer, Geoffrey">Chaucer</rs> who</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">goes ahead, simply, directly, <del>It</del> The Knights, the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">ladies, <del>become</del> <del>loo</del> are <del>see</del> disembodied:</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>what</del> & <del>the</del> But <del>we cannot leave</del> it unread:</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">it has <del>the vitality of the</del> we see it: the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>compound</del> in groups, like <del>[illeg.]</del> the great</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">caravans, painted, brought together into <del>the</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the [illeg.] comes together on the [finial?]</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">from the ground. Sometimes the comment is</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">perfectly free, expressive <del>of some</del> still of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">some emotion; & then the [warbly]</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">becomes sound merely, the [illeg.] merely,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">an incantation; & it passes</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">away like a cloud; sleep, indifference,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">[illeg.], along the ear, – still</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">we must return to it, because of the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">language – partly for that love of the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">old they seem: it is the thing itself: not </l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wmor" key="Morris, William">Morris</rs> or <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-aten" key="Tennyson, Alfred">Tennyson</rs>: <del>it is</del> & [pearly?]</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a [illeg.] such a poem as an exile might</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">write by way of refuge from the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">damp <del>of</del> & the savagery of the Irish</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">country</l>
